bibl.title: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to George A. Kellogg, July 31, 1941

div1.p: Kean approves of the finished Cornwell painting. He comments on the various figures depicted in the work.

div1.head: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to George A. Kellogg, July 31, 1941
div1.opener:
C O P Y
2804 N. Street, N.W.
Washington, D.C.
July 31, 1941
Mr. George A. Kellogg,
257 Cornelison Avenue
Jersey City, N J.
My dear Mr. Kellogg:
div1.p:
I pray you will not take the delay in acknowledging
your kind letter of July 24, sending us the reproduction in
color of Mr. Cornwell's find painting “The Conquerors of
Yellow Fever”. We were in Richmond, Virginia, on a visit to
my son and no mail was sent to us while there. When I re-
turned on the 29th I was sick and went from the automobile
to my bed from which I arose this morning feeling well enough
to drive a pen.

Mr. Cornwell has made a most interesting and striking
group and has been more successful than I would have thought
possible in bringing so many figures together in a natural
and easy grouping. I don't think my face was ever round and
am quite satisfied with it. My friend Truby did have a round
smooth face with a pleasing expression and no prominence of
check bones. I think that Major Reed is excellent--his face has
the look of intentness which was characteristic of him but
without the scowl which has sometimes been given him. He. and
Dr. Finlay are the most important figure in the group. As you
know, I did not favor my inclusion or Truby's and General Wood's
in the group, but I can see that I was too factual-minded for the
most effective artistic results.

You may be interested to learn that the first letter
we opened referring to it was from Mrs. Leonard Wood, the widow
of Major Gen. Leonard Wood, written from his birthplace at
Pocasset, Mass. which belongs to their daughter, Luisita (who
was born in the Governor General's palace in Havana.) She
seemed much pleased with it. If Mr. Cornwell is assailed with
the comment that Kean had no right to be there, he can say with
truth that the Sec'ty of War, in his annual report for 1900-1
in mentioning this episode, commended Carroll and Kean in the
same sentence.

Mrs. Kean joins me in thanking you for remembering
us in this pleasant way and we both wish to be remembered to
Robin.

closer.seg:
P.S. July 31, 1941. This is a P.S. to my letter of today's date to say that my commendation
for the yellow fever work was in the report of Elihu Root, Sec'ty of War for the f.y.1901-02
which I think is a year later than the date I gave in my leter. Please make the correction.
J. R. Kean
